results.adx_keywords: Kyle, Chris (1974-2013);Routh, Eddie Ray;Murders and Attempted Murders;American Sniper: The Autobiography of the Most Lethal Sniper in U.S. Military History (Book);Navy Seals;Texas
results.byline: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ
results.title: Untouchable in Iraq, Ex-Sniper Dies in a Shooting Back Home
results.abstract: Chris Kyle, a former Navy SEAL, had taken a troubled fellow veteran to a gun range for a kind of therapy session, but the police said the man turned his gun on Mr. Kyle.

media.caption: Chris Kyle in 2012.
media.copyright: Paul Moseley/The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, via Associated Press

media.caption: Chris Kyle in 2012.

results.adx_keywords: Drugs (Pharmaceuticals);Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder;Adderall (Drug);Education (K-12);Youth;Addiction (Psychology);Psychiatry and Psychiatrists;Fee, Richard;Fee, Rick;Fee, Kathy;Doctors;Mental Health and Disorders
results.title: Drowned in a Stream of Prescriptions
results.abstract: The suicide of Richard Fee highlights issues in the treatment of A.D.H.D., as youths fake symptoms to feed their addictions to potentially dangerous stimulants.

media.caption: Before his addiction, Richard Fee was a popular college class president and aspiring medical student. "You keep giving Adderall to my son, you're going to kill him," said Rick Fee, Richard's father, to one of his son's doctors.

MENTAL HEALTH CLINIC Dominion Psychiatric Associates in Virginia Beach, where Richard Fee was treated by Dr. Waldo M. Ellison. After observing Richard and hearing his complaints about concentration, Dr. Ellison diagnosed attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and prescribed the stimulant Adderall.
media.copyright: Matt Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: COLLEGE YEARS Richard Fee was on the baseball team at Greensboro College.
media.copyright: Matthew Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: PARENTS Kathy and Rick Fee with a photograph of Richard, who committed suicide in November 2011. They say they begged his doctors not to prescribe Adderall, an amphetamine to which he had become addicted. One of Richard’s doctors later said that his was a textbook case of the ways A.D.H.D. practices can fail patients.
media.copyright: Matthew Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: QUESTIONNAIRE Richard Fee first received a diagnosis of A.D.H.D. in 2009, during a visit to a psychiatric clinic where he filled out a survey rating symptoms on a 0-to-3 scale. Having used stimulants in college to study, Richard appeared to have faked his responses in order to get a prescription.
PSYCHIATRIST Dr. Charles Parker was one of the doctors who saw Richard Fee.
media.copyright: Matthew Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: SNAPSHOT Rick and Richard Fee at Yankee Stadium in November 2009. As Richard’s addiction worsened, he became more violent and eventually was asked to leave his parents’ home.
media.copyright: Matthew Eich for The New York Times

media.caption: Before his addiction, Richard Fee was a popular college class president and aspiring medical student. "You keep giving Adderall to my son, you're going to kill him," said Rick Fee, Richard's father, to one of his son's doctors.

results.title: In Hard Economy for All Ages, Older Isn’t Better ... It’s Brutal
results.abstract: Recent data present a strong case for baby boomers as the greatest victims of the recession and its grim aftermath.

media.caption: Susan Zimmerman, 62, has three part-time jobs.
media.copyright: David Maxwell for The New York Times

media.caption: Arynita Armstrong, 60, at her home in Willis, Tex. She last worked five years ago. “When you’re older, they just see gray hair and they write you off,” she says.
media.copyright: Michael Stravato for The New York Times

results.title: Israeli Strike Into Syria Said to Damage Research Site
results.abstract: The weapons research center has been the target of sanctions because of intelligence suggesting that it was the training site for engineers who worked on chemical and biological weaponry.
des_facet: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )

media.caption: Rebel fighters received instructions during heavy fighting on Sunday in Damascus. Rebels’ cellphone videos showed damage caused by an Israeli raid Wednesday.
A Free Syrian Army fighter was wounded by a sniper in Damascus on Sunday. An Israeli airstrike last week showed cracks in Syria’s system of defense.
Rebel fighters received instructions during heavy fighting on Sunday in Damascus. Rebels’ cellphone videos showed damage caused by an Israeli raid Wednesday.

results.title: Top Donors to Republicans Seek More Say in Senate Races
results.abstract: The Republican Party’s biggest donors are financing a new group to recruit seasoned candidates and protect Senate incumbents from challenges by far-right conservatives and Tea Party enthusiasts.

media.caption: Representative Steve King of Iowa could be an early target of the Conservative Victory Project.
Steven J. Law, a leader of the Conservative Victory Project, say they are taking steps to steer Mr. King away from a Senate run.
media.copyright: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times

media.caption: Representative Steve King of Iowa could be an early target of the Conservative Victory Project.

results.title: Why Police Lie Under Oath
results.abstract: Perversely, the criminal justice system gives officers an incentive to perjure themselves.

results.title: The Boy With a Thorn in His Joints
results.abstract: When 3-year-old Shepherd Strauss got sick, his parents turned to doctors and drugs. But they couldn’t anticipate that what would help him feel better didn’t come with a prescription.

media.caption: Shepherd Strauss, who was diagnosed with juvenile idiopathic arthritis when he was 3.
media.copyright: Olivia Bee for The New York Times

media.caption: The author and Shepherd, now 5, almost two years after receiving a diagnosis of juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
media.copyright: Olivia Bee for The New York Times

results.title: Dangerous Gun Myths
results.abstract: The idea that weapons make women and homes safer is wrong. The opposite is true.

results.title: Beyoncé Silences Doubters With Intensity at Halftime
results.abstract: Beyoncé answered her critics during her halftime performance by singing live with fierceness and confidence. Late in her set, she was joined by her former sidekicks of Destiny’s Child.

media.caption: Beyoncé opened her halftime performance with a serious tone, singing her hit “Love on Top.” Her voice was fierce and powerful for “Crazy in Love.”

results.title: Power Fails and 49ers Surge, but Ravens Win
results.abstract: After a game delay because of a power failure, M.V.P. Joe Flacco and the Ravens, leading 28-6, withstood a determined comeback by the 49ers to win the Super Bowl.

results.adx_keywords: Mercedes Benz Superdome (New Orleans);Super Bowl;Baltimore Ravens;San Francisco 49ers;Power Outages and Blackouts;Football
results.title: Before Game is Decided, Superdome Goes Dark
results.abstract: The lights on one half of the Superdome’s roof suddenly went out, making for one of the oddest, most embarrassing moments in Super Bowl history.

media.caption: A security guard Sunday during the power failure at the Super Dome in New Orleans, with the emergency lights on.
San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick on the field during the power failure. He later led the Niners back from a 28-6 deficit.
media.copyright: Jed Jacobsohn for The New York Times

media.caption: A security guard Sunday during the power failure at the Super Dome in New Orleans, with the emergency lights on.

results.title: The Most Wanted Gun in America
results.abstract: Aggressive marketing and savvy manufacturing have helped recast the place of guns in American life, turning AR-15-style rifles into a fast-growing profit center.

media.caption: At the Pasadena Pawn and Gun Shop in Maryland, customers can join a waiting list to buy an AR-15-style rifle. “It’s kind of fashionable,” Frank Loane Sr., the shop’s proprietor, said of the gun.
media.copyright: Steve Ruark for The New York Times

results.title: Amid All the Contradictions, Another Championship for Lewis
results.abstract: Even in festive New Orleans, the mood for Ray Lewis’s retirement party had been subdued, but the celebration began anew after the Ravens’ victory, sending Lewis out in style.

media.caption: Ray Lewis, who said the Super Bowl would be the final game of his 17-year career, celebrating the Ravens’ 34-31 victory.
Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis before the Super Bowl, which he said would be the final game of his 17-year N.F.L. career.
media.copyright: Jed Jacobsohn for The New York Times

media.caption: The Ravens’ Ray Lewis, playing in his second Super Bowl, closing in on 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick in the first quarter of Sunday’s game.
Ray Lewis, who said the Super Bowl would be the final game of his 17-year career, celebrating the Ravens’ 34-31 victory.
